div.p: Punctuation goes inside structure tags but always outside content tags.
The period is outside the content element of "cause" even though it ends the sentence, but inside the structure tag of CHRONRPOSE.

Punctuate quotations generally in MLA style. The commonest punctuation marks (comma, period) go inside quotation marks even if not so in the original; semi-colons, dashes, etc., if not in original, go outside quote marks. EXCEPTION: because of the nature of our tagging, place period BEFORE a bibcit (according to MLA style periods go after parenthetical citations, but we judge that BIBCITs display better outside punctuation).

If you are using the quote tag and wondering about how to punctuate, use the following guidelines: put punctuation inside sentences and longish phrases; outside punctuation for mere words and phrases (three words or less). We can be less strict about the use of punctuation around the quote tag because the content inside it will not be sorted in the same way that the information within a title tag will be sorted. For instance, our delivery system would not be able to equate The Waves with The Waves. because of the period, but we will never be sorting quotations in quite the same way.
Please use a comma before the final and in lists. For example, write x, y, and z rather than x, y and z.
Do not punctuate titles such as Mrs and Mr, etc. if the final letter of the word is present in the abbreviation. See also Abbreviations.
If you wish to use a long dash for emphasis in your writing, please use the entity emdash (look under entities). Use it with no spaces on either side.

When using ellipses, please place a space between the periods: . . . . Four periods indicate that the omission contained a period, three that it did not. Donâ€™t render the three periods in an ellipsis without spaces between them.
